title: Torque - evidence for rope force at points Q and R

content.question: A horizontal pole can rotate vertically about a pivot that is attached to a wall at Point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math>, as shown in the figure. A fixed ring is located higher up on the wall, <math alttext="1.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.2</mn></math> meters above the pivot, where a rope can be attached to support the pole. The figures show two possible attachment points on the pole for the rope, at points <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math> and <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>R</mtext></math>. If the rope tension results in the same torque <math alttext="tau sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>Ï„</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math> for both attachment points, for which attachment point is the rope tension greater? What evidence supports reasoning for the claim?

choices.label: Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math>. The rope is shorter when attached to Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math>.

Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math>. The lever arm is shorter when the rope is attached to Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math>.

Point <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>R</mtext></math>. The rope is longer when attached to Point <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>R</mtext></math>.

Point <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>R</mtext></math>. The lever arm is longer when the rope is attached to Point <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>R</mtext></math>.

content.answer: Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math>. The lever arm is shorter when the rope is attached to Point <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Q</mtext></math>.
